title: Iranian weapons used in oil facilities attack, Saudi Arabia claims
text:
Smoke from a fire at the Abqaiq oil processing facility fills the skyline, in Buqyaq, Saudi Arabia. - Al-Arabiya

Saudi Arabia has claimed Iranian weapons were used in the attacks on its oil facilities though stopped short of blaming its arch-enemy directly, as crude prices hit record highs.

Col. Turki al-Malki, a Saudi military spokesman, said their initial investigations showed Iranian weapons were used in the weekend attack on the country's oil installations, but it was still determining where they had been launched.

Missiles hit vital infrastructure at Khurais oilfield and Abqaiq petroleum processing plant - the world’s largest - on Saturday, crippling production.

A satellite image shows an apparent drone strike on an Aramco oil facility in Saudi Arabia Credit: Planet Labs More

US President Donald Trump had warned Tehran that the US was “locked and loaded”, though qualified that it would wait for a decision from ally Saudi on how to respond.

“We don’t need Middle Eastern Oil & Gas, & in fact have very few tankers there, but will help our Allies! (sic),” Mr Trump tweeted.

A mooted meeting between Mr Trump and his Iranian counterpart Hassan Rouhani at the United Nations later this month appeared off the cards after Tehran said it would not be happening and the US president called it “fake news”.

Saturday's attack halted production of 5.7 million barrels of crude a day, more than half of Saudi Arabia's global daily exports and more than 5 per cent of the world's daily crude oil production. Most of that output goes to Asia.

At 5.7 million barrels of crude oil a day, the Saudi disruption would be the greatest on record for world markets.

Mr Trump tried in vain to calm the markets, tweeting: ““PLENTY OF OIL!”

The Houthis, a Shia group aligned with Iran fighting Saudi-backed government in Yemen, claimed responsibility for the attacks and warned “our long hand can reach wherever we want whenever we want.”

However, experts and officials say it was unlikely to have been the militia, which they say lacks the capability to carry out such a highly orchestrated attack inside the kingdom.

“This wasn’t done by an amateur, to put it very mildly,” tweeted Carl Bildt, co-chair of the European Council on Foreign Relations . “It was a massive and highly sophisticated attack.”

A US official told ABC news that said Iran launched nearly a dozen cruise missiles and over 20 drones from its territory.

“It was Iran. The Houthis are claiming credit for something they did not do,” they said.

Story continues
